Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection a fire extinguisher door cover located in the shelter side of the operation, was observed to have a broken glass and the glass door covering was not secured properly.
Correction Narrative: High Sky GRO Director submitted compliance via email on 1/13/2025. A photograph of the replaced glass and secured clips holder for the fire extinguisher was provided.

Deficiency Narrative: When a child in care presented with difficult behaviors, an employee covered the mouth of a child and pushed them away.
Correction Narrative:
RCCR inspector received compliance follow up from program director on 9/23/24. 

Staff involved in citation was terminated on 8/16/24 for behavior towards child in care.

Following the incident, the operation implemented the requirement to have two staff members in the vehicle when transporting this child in care. Staff increased the Childs safety plan focus on prevention of behaviors during transport. The safety plan can be found in document library.

Deficiency Narrative: Child in care had multiple injuries where staff were unaware of how the injuries were obtained. The child in care continued to be injured showing a lack of prevention and steps taken to ensure safety.
Correction Narrative:
RCCR Inspector received compliance plan from Program Director on 8/29/24. GRO Director and GRO Manager will increase unannounced in-home observations of staff interactions with youth. Staff will receive feedback on how they can improve active supervision of youth to ensure safety and well-being. If GRO Director or GRO Manager identify areas of risk, measures will be implemented to increase prevention of injuries.


RCCR inspector conducted a follow up inspection on 9/10/24. Inspector conducted a walkthrough of the facility with no plain site concerns. The inspector spoke to three staff who stated when a child is injured, an incident report is made and a supervisor and case manager is contacted. Staff stated they check the children each day for bruises/scratches and injuries. They use a check mark system to document the checks. Staff stated supervision is discussed weekly in staff meetings and trainings periodically on injuries.

Deficiency Narrative: A child in care was not assessed by a medical professional after receiving multiple injuries.
Correction Narrative:
RCCR inspector received compliance plan from program director on 8/29/24. The operation will continue with health and well-being scans at the beginning of each shift to check for injuries or illness. If trends or patterns are identified with injuries to a youth, preventative measures will be put in place to reduce risk for the youth. When we have a serious injury, we will seek appropriate medical attention.

RCCR inspector conducted a follow up inspection on 9/10/24. Inspector conducted a walkthrough of the facility with no plain site concerns. The inspector spoke to three staff who stated when a child is injured, an incident report is made and a supervisor and case manager is contacted. Staff stated they check the children each day for bruises/scratches and injuries. They use a check mark system to document the checks. Staff stated supervision is discussed weekly in staff meetings and trainings periodically on injuries.

Deficiency Narrative: A child in care sustained multiple accidental injuries in a short time span. Multiple staff were unable to explain how and when the injuries are occurring
Correction Narrative:
RCCR inspector was emailed compliance plan from GRO Program Director on 7/25/24. Director conducted a training focused on creating a culture of safety on 7/18/24. The PowerPoint will be uploaded to document library. The Director met with the team virtually to discuss the standard and the importance of following through with active supervision. A copy of the standards related to supervision were provided to all staff for reviews. 

RCCR inspector conducted a follow up walk through at the operation on 8/9/24. Staff were actively monitoring and in ratio with 4 children in care. Staff and children were both interviewed about supervision. There were no further concerns.

Deficiency Narrative: Three children, two collateral staff members, and one professional collateral reported similar concerns of a staff member making a child uncomfortable when waking them up, calling a child a disappointment, and speaking to children about wanting to adopt them.
Correction Narrative:
RCCR Inspector received a follow up email from the GRO Director on 4/9/24. All staff reviewed a Prudent Parent Judgement training as well as their signatures indicating their understanding of their responsibilities. The training and staff signatures were added to the document library. 
The staff involved was moved to another home with younger children, rather than teenagers, during the investigation.

Deficiency Narrative: Three children in care did not have a discharge plan from the emergency shelter.
Correction Narrative:
Program Director emailed the inspector the completed the preliminary discharge plan that will be used for children in care at the emergency shelter. The plan will include Anticipated Discharge Date, Emergency Care Services Placement End Date, Recommendations for Future Placement Type/Setting, Type of Care, Level of Supervision, and Services Needed, Efforts Reported by DFPS
Efforts of Current Placement to Prepare for Discharge/Transition, Immediate Needs Upon Discharge, Reviewed By and Review Date. The document is uploaded into the document library.

Deficiency Narrative: The operation does not have an overall operation evaluation for Emergency Behavior Intervention.
Correction Narrative: On 1/17/24, Program Director emailed the inspect follow up compliance of the GRO Overall Operation Evaluation. The evaluation states a total of four restraints were conducted in 2023. All restraints were in the emergency shelter, and all occurred in the month of July. One child was restrained three 􀆟times. Two staff conducted 2 of the 4 restraints. Both youth restrained were siblings. There were no notable injuries to youth. There was one notable injury to staff. The evaluation was uploaded to the document library.

Deficiency Narrative: A caregiver failed to supervise children resulting in children engaging in inappropriate sexual behavior.
Correction Narrative: Compliance was discussed with the operation's administrator and the administrator sent an email stating what was discussed during the exit conference that they will increase supervision when only staff is on shift, medication administration will occur in common areas of the shelter, instead of in the medication room, to allow better line of sight for the caregiver. The administrator believes this change to their procedures will reduce areas of vulnerability in supervision.

Deficiency Narrative: A child's medication log did not have the time for two different medications.
Correction Narrative: Received compliance from Christina Raines, Administrator. Christina stated the medication logs that were reviewed have been corrected. Christina attached the corrected documents on email. The medication logs for the medication Buspirone 5 mg and Isentress 400 mg were corrected. Christina stated that GRO Manager Carli Field met with the employee who made the errors and counseled her on proper medication log procedures.

Deficiency Narrative: A couple of children stayed at the emergency shelter past 90 days. A variance for a placement extension was requested until 8/31/2022.
Correction Narrative: Received compliance from the Administrator stating as discussed with RCCR Inspector, variances for placement extensions will be requested going forward. The administrator had inquired with RCCR Inspector about the need for variances on 8/30/2022 and began requesting variances on 8/31/2022 based on RCCR Inspector's guidance. The operation will ensure the children do not go beyond the 90 days of emergency placement without a variance request.

Deficiency Narrative: Medication logs for a couple of children did not have the time when the medication was administered on 7/03/2022.
Correction Narrative: RCCR Inspector Sandra Melgar received email from the GRO Administrator stating that they remedied the medication log errors by speaking with the employees who were responsible for the errors noted in the inspection. The employees were able to cross-reference the other medication logs administered on the same day and same time and correct their error. Further, all employees were counseled on the importance of maintaining proper medication administration documentation. The GRO Manager is conducting more frequent medication log reviews to ensure errors are caught early.

Deficiency Narrative: A staff member struggled, and continued to participate, in an incident with a child in care.
Correction Narrative:
High Sky's Shelter Director Christina Raines emailed Inspector Jordan Green the compliance plan on 5/20/22. 
High Sky Childrens Ranch takes matters of youth care and safety seriously and has created the following plan to achieve compliance with Standard 748.507 (1):  
 
May 19, 2022: Staff attended a one- hour training focused on maintaining self-control during times of stress.   
 
In June, staff will attend individualized developmental meetings with their supervisor. Staff will be asked to identify their strengths and weaknesses in areas of prudent judgment, self-control, and competence in approved techniques to manage youth behavior. The Shelter Director and Shelter Manager will provide feedback, monitoring, and further training as deemed necessary to improve their skill sets and ensure appropriate care of youth in care.  
 
Monthly program meetings will focus on areas identified as needing further training in areas of competency, self-control, and prudent judgment.  
 
Guidance and verbiage from the Technical Assistance Given will be reviewed with staff at monthly program meetings and when reviewing youth service plans to help caregivers make informed and careful decisions when interacting with youth to ensure safety and build trust with youth.  
 
Non-prudent judgement and inappropriate interactions with youth will not be tolerated by High Sky Childrens Ranch. Appropriate disciplinary and corrective action has been taken with the employee related to this incident and will be taken if any further incidents should occur.

Deficiency Narrative: A caregiver used profanity towards a child in care such as "cunt", "bitch" and "little bitch".
Correction Narrative: Received an email from Christina Raines, Administrator at High Sky Children's Ranch GRO stating that on 5/19/2022, she led a training with staff on managing their own emotions when dealing with youth behaviors. This training also covered in pre-service for all new staff and twice per year for existing staff. The staff member that was investigated was terminated on 4/26/2022, this is the same day the incident occurred.

Deficiency Narrative: A caregiver made inappropriate comments towards a child in care stating that by the child's 18th birthday the child would ended up in jail due to the child's previous arrest.
Correction Narrative: Received an email from Christina Raines, Administrator at High Sky Children's Ranch GRO stating that on 5/19/2022, she led a training with staff on managing their own emotions when dealing with youth behaviors. This training also covered in pre-service for all new staff and twice per year for existing staff. The staff member that was investigated was terminated on 4/26/2022, this is the same day the incident occurred.
